quizTitle: Module 3: Start - Laying the Base Quiz
quizSynopsis: Test your knowledge of defining goals, modularity, testing and QA, unit tests, Docker best practices, and continuous integration concepts including GitHub Actions and quality gates.

questions.question: What is the first step when starting a new project according to the module?
questions.messageForCorrectAnswer: Correct! Planning begins with clearly defining goals and requirements.
questions.messageForIncorrectAnswer: Incorrect. You must define goals and requirements before starting.

questions.question: Why choose an Agile methodology like Kanban from the start?
answers: Because Agile methods like Kanban help visualize and manage work effectively
questions.messageForCorrectAnswer: Correct! Kanban helps visualize workflow and improve continuous delivery.
questions.messageForIncorrectAnswer: Incorrect. Kanban supports visual management of tasks and adaptability.

questions.question: What should you assume about project documentation?
answers: No one else will read it
Only write it at the end
Someone else may read it at any phase, so keep it clear and updated
questions.messageForCorrectAnswer: Correct! Document as you go, assuming others will read it anytime.
questions.messageForIncorrectAnswer: Incorrect. Documentation should be clear and continuous.

questions.question: How can you avoid scope creep?
answers: By adding every new idea immediately
By making it work, then make it right, then make it fast
questions.messageForCorrectAnswer: Correct! Focus on essential features first, then refine and optimize.
questions.messageForIncorrectAnswer: Incorrect. Avoid scope creep by prioritizing and staging improvements.

questions.question: What does being a 'Manager of One' mean?
answers: Setting your own goals and executing them with minimal supervision
questions.messageForCorrectAnswer: Correct! A manager of one is self-directed and takes initiative.
questions.messageForIncorrectAnswer: Incorrect. A manager of one works independently and proactively.

questions.question: Why is modularity in code beneficial?
answers: It makes the code harder to understand
It allows separation of concerns, easier testing, and reusability
questions.messageForCorrectAnswer: Correct! Modularity simplifies maintenance, testing, and updates.
questions.messageForIncorrectAnswer: Incorrect. Modularity improves code quality and manageability.

questions.question: What should you avoid when splitting code into modules?
answers: Over-engineering by creating too many micro modules unnecessarily
Keeping code in a single file always
questions.messageForCorrectAnswer: Correct! Balance modularity with simplicity and avoid unnecessary complexity.
questions.messageForIncorrectAnswer: Incorrect. Too many tiny modules can complicate the codebase.

questions.question: Why should you always aim for clarity and simplicity in code?
answers: Because code is rarely read by others
Because complex code is easier to debug
Because code is read more than it's written; future maintainers need clarity
questions.messageForCorrectAnswer: Correct! Future developers (including your future self) benefit from clear code.
questions.messageForIncorrectAnswer: Incorrect. Code clarity aids maintainability and understanding.

questions.question: Does language choice matter when applying modular and reusable principles?
answers: No, the principles apply regardless of language
questions.messageForCorrectAnswer: Correct! Modularity and reusability principles apply to any language.
questions.messageForIncorrectAnswer: Incorrect. The same coding principles hold across all technologies.

questions.question: Why is reusability important for a DevOps engineer?
answers: It avoids solving problems more than once and improves efficiency
questions.messageForCorrectAnswer: Correct! Reusability saves effort, reduces duplication, and improves consistency.
questions.messageForIncorrectAnswer: Incorrect. Reuse code to be more efficient and consistent.

questions.question: What is the primary goal of testing and QA?
answers: To ensure the software meets requirements and is as defect-free as possible
questions.messageForCorrectAnswer: Correct! Testing and QA aim to deliver reliable, requirement-meeting software.
questions.messageForIncorrectAnswer: Incorrect. QA ensures quality and correctness.

questions.question: How are testing and QA often related?
answers: They are usually used interchangeably, though technically different
questions.messageForCorrectAnswer: Correct! They’re not the same but often treated similarly.
questions.messageForIncorrectAnswer: Incorrect. While related, QA and testing have distinct focuses.

questions.question: Why should DevOps engineers care about testing their own code?
answers: Because they never interact with code
Because only QA specialists test code
Because ensuring code quality is part of DevOps responsibilities
questions.messageForCorrectAnswer: Correct! DevOps engineers also ensure their code and tools are reliable.
questions.messageForIncorrectAnswer: Incorrect. DevOps includes ensuring code quality and reliability.

questions.question: Which testing type checks if individual components work correctly in isolation?
questions.messageForCorrectAnswer: Correct! Unit testing verifies the correctness of small, isolated units of code.
questions.messageForIncorrectAnswer: Incorrect. Unit tests focus on individual code pieces.

questions.question: What type of testing verifies the system meets user requirements and is ready for release?
questions.messageForCorrectAnswer: Correct! Acceptance tests confirm readiness against user expectations.
questions.messageForIncorrectAnswer: Incorrect. Acceptance testing checks readiness for release.

questions.question: What is the focus of unit tests?
answers: Testing large integrated systems at once
Testing small components in isolation for correctness
questions.messageForCorrectAnswer: Correct! Unit tests validate individual functions or modules independently.
questions.messageForIncorrectAnswer: Incorrect. Unit tests are about small, isolated code units.

questions.question: Why are frameworks or libraries often used for unit testing?
answers: To provide a structured way to write, run, and report tests
questions.messageForCorrectAnswer: Correct! Testing frameworks streamline test development and execution.
questions.messageForIncorrectAnswer: Incorrect. Frameworks make testing easier and more consistent.

questions.question: Is 100% unit test coverage always necessary?
answers: No, 100% coverage isn’t always valuable or realistic
You should never write unit tests
questions.messageForCorrectAnswer: Correct! Aim for meaningful coverage rather than arbitrary 100%.
questions.messageForIncorrectAnswer: Incorrect. Perfect coverage isn't always worth it.

questions.question: What should the complexity level of unit test code be?
questions.messageForCorrectAnswer: Correct! Keep unit tests simple and focused.
questions.messageForIncorrectAnswer: Incorrect. Simplicity ensures tests are reliable helpers.

questions.question: Why start applying Docker best practices now?
answers: Because following best practices ensures efficient, secure, and maintainable container images
questions.messageForCorrectAnswer: Correct! Early adoption of Docker best practices improves quality and stability.
questions.messageForIncorrectAnswer: Incorrect. Good practices streamline container management.

questions.question: What is Hadolint?
answers: A Dockerfile linter to check against common best practices
questions.messageForCorrectAnswer: Correct! Hadolint flags Dockerfile issues and suggests improvements.
questions.messageForIncorrectAnswer: Incorrect. Hadolint is a tool for Dockerfile linting.

questions.question: Do you need to memorize all Docker best practices?
answers: No, use tools and references to guide you
questions.messageForCorrectAnswer: Correct! Reference tools and docs instead of memorizing everything.
questions.messageForIncorrectAnswer: Incorrect. Let tools guide you instead of relying on memory.

questions.question: What are some categories of Docker best practices?
answers: Common, language-specific, security, container file, image, runtime
questions.messageForCorrectAnswer: Correct! Best practices cover multiple aspects: common, security, runtime, etc.
questions.messageForIncorrectAnswer: Incorrect. There are various categories of best practices.

questions.question: Why is Continuous Integration (CI) important?
answers: It ensures code changes are regularly merged, tested, and validated early
It only applies to large companies
questions.messageForCorrectAnswer: Correct! CI catches errors early and maintains quality as code evolves.
questions.messageForIncorrectAnswer: Incorrect. CI streamlines integration and quality control.

questions.question: Which CI system is suggested for beginners?
answers: Start with a complicated proprietary system
Start with GitHub Actions for simplicity
questions.messageForCorrectAnswer: Correct! GitHub Actions is straightforward and integrated into GitHub.
questions.messageForIncorrectAnswer: Incorrect. GitHub Actions is simpler for beginners than Jenkins.

questions.question: What is the main purpose of CI?
answers: To detect errors quickly and ensure code quality with frequent integrations
questions.messageForCorrectAnswer: Correct! CI quickly identifies issues, improving code quality and flow.
questions.messageForIncorrectAnswer: Incorrect. CI aims to integrate and verify code regularly.

questions.question: Does the choice of CI system matter much at the start?
answers: No, principles matter more than specific tools
You must use only GitLab CI
questions.messageForCorrectAnswer: Correct! Understanding CI principles is more important than the tool.
questions.messageForIncorrectAnswer: Incorrect. The underlying principles are key.

questions.question: What are GitHub Actions 'Workflows'?
answers: The YAML configurations defining automation like build/test pipelines
questions.messageForCorrectAnswer: Correct! Workflows are YAML files defining automated processes.
questions.messageForIncorrectAnswer: Incorrect. Workflows define CI/CD steps in GitHub Actions.

questions.question: In GitHub Actions, what is a 'job'?
answers: A set of steps that run on the same machine
questions.messageForCorrectAnswer: Correct! A job contains multiple steps on one runner machine.
questions.messageForIncorrectAnswer: Incorrect. A job groups steps to run together.

questions.question: What are 'Actions' in GitHub Actions?
answers: Reusable units of code performing specific tasks
questions.messageForCorrectAnswer: Correct! Actions are reusable components that perform defined tasks.
questions.messageForIncorrectAnswer: Incorrect. Actions are like plugins that add functionality.

questions.question: How do jobs in GitHub Actions run by default?
questions.messageForCorrectAnswer: Correct! Jobs are parallel by default but can be sequenced with dependencies.
questions.messageForIncorrectAnswer: Incorrect. Jobs typically run in parallel unless dependencies are set.

questions.question: Why implement pipelines and quality gates in CI?
answers: To ensure changes meet certain standards before proceeding
questions.messageForCorrectAnswer: Correct! Quality gates ensure code meets standards before merging.
questions.messageForIncorrectAnswer: Incorrect. Quality gates maintain code quality and reliability.

questions.question: Should all CI checks be hard to run locally?
answers: No, it's recommended they can run locally to catch issues early
questions.messageForCorrectAnswer: Correct! Running checks locally prevents wasting CI resources and time.
questions.messageForIncorrectAnswer: Incorrect. Local checks catch issues before pushing.

questions.question: What tool can help run essential checks before committing code?
answers: A random script with no standards
Pre-commit hooks to enforce quality gates locally
questions.messageForCorrectAnswer: Correct! Pre-commit hooks enforce quality checks before code enters the repo.
questions.messageForIncorrectAnswer: Incorrect. Pre-commit hooks ensure quality early.

questions.question: Why integrate linting and code style checks into CI pipelines?
answers: To ensure consistent code quality and style
questions.messageForCorrectAnswer: Correct! Linting and style checks maintain consistency and readability.
questions.messageForIncorrectAnswer: Incorrect. Style checks keep the code clean and uniform.
